Excuse me, what are you... who are you?
So you're the famous Jim Jode, the talk of the Royal Society!
Please, Mr. Holmes. I've read Dr. Watsons stories. What are you doing here? Am I being accused of something?
My name is Sherlock Holmes. Here with some questions I'd like you to answer.
How do you mean? Am I being accused of something?
Professor Chauncey has been recently proclaimed dead. Do you know anything about it?
What? I... Goodness. We had our differences, but he didn't deserve it. Not at all.
You seem to be a keen chemist. A fine hobby - I couldn't think of a better one myself.
It's more than a hobby.
I aim to be the youngest member of the Royal Society of Chemistry. I have already found an existing member to sponsor me!
Professor Chauncey wanted you expelled, did he not?
Yes, he did. We had our differences from the very beginning... Hold on, am I under suspicion?
Mere idle curiosity on my part. I meant no insult.
Hmph. None taken then.
You can't deny you had a motive.
Yes I can. Sure we quarreled - he isn't- wasn't the easiest to get along with. But this is murder you are talking about!
Can you recall where you were at the time the Professor died?
Absolutely. I was at home the whole time, right here.
I ran experiments, dozens of them. Not all of them successful - I had to step outside and explain the smell to all the neighbours.
I see.
Now, if that is all, I need to leave in a moment, and I must ask you to leave, too. Otherwise I'll have to call the police.
Let's not involve the bobbies, young Jim. I will depart immediately.
There you are, Tom Jode. How's your leg?
Why, what business is that of yours?
You have a brother called Jim, correct?
What do you need from him? You give him any trouble I'll break your bloody neck!
Oh, it's not me who got him into trouble.
The sordid business of Professor Chauncey's death.
What are you talkin' 'bout? I don't know no professors, sir, I'm just a worker here!
A superstitious man with a weak heart, scared to death by a Limping Devil - a roundabout method of murder, but it worked, didn't it?
I... bollocks. Look, hear me out first.
Let's see what you have to say.
Jim told me everything about the guy, brother to brother. I did plan on givin' him a spook. Made that silly suit.
Wanted to make a scene, tell the man he was too old to make enemies. But when I woke him up he clutched his chest and went quiet.
With a mind like yours you could excel at the university, Tom.
Aye, and who'd pay for it? Me and Jim got nobody. I figured I'd give one of us a chance.
When someone threatened that, I had to act. But I swear, I didn't mean to kill the old man!
You should hope Inspector Lestrade finds your story convincing, because I don't. A murder is a murder.
Sir, you are making a mistake! Who will pay for Jim's studies now?! What will he do?
I have to admit, your creativity is incredibly amusing. For the sake of young Jim's future we will keep this between ourselves.
But once his studies are done...
I will go to the police myself, sir. I promise you.
What happened here? Tell me everything.
It was the devil! The devil came for our poor Professor and took his soul!
There was fire, and brimstone, and that horrible barking of his!
Did you catch the devil in the act, by any chance?
Of course not! I was terrified! I only saw his awful horned shadow as he lept into the window!
Barking, you said?
Yes. Barking like a hound dog! No ordinary human could make a noise like that!
Fire and brimstone, you say?
You can still smell it! Oh, our poor Professor...
Thank you, your testimony was indispensable. That will be all.
Linear dialog will be here
A dialog with two choices will be here
Hell yeah!
Nope.
Will the dialog with three choices be here?
Yeah, sure
No way it cam fit
Think twice about it!
Good day, let me through, please! I've brought materials for Jim Jode.
What materials? Who are you?!
Dangerous materials, incredibly hazardous - only for proficient chemists, like me and Jim.
Slightest hand contact may cause stuttering, blindness and premature hair loss. Would you rather take them to Jim's room for me?
No, no! Goodness no, just go on. Good Lord, that Jode and his experiments!
I shall only be a minute or two. Goodbye.
Good day to you, sir. My name is Sherlock Holmes...
Thomas Garrett. Why am I here? "coughing"
You are a witness to murder.
Of course. Well, it wouldn't be the first time that the police jailed an innocent man in order to close a case...
No-one has been charged yet.
Yet... "coughing"
Did you perhaps see anything in particular during or after this disaster?
Yes, I saw part of your bourgeoisie burn up and explode... it was spectacular!
You have a severe cough. Are you suffering?
It's only a cold... "coughing"
Why not be honest with me? You are spitting up black fluid.
Ah!! Well observed... Yes, I have enough coal dust in my lungs to fuel an entire London district...
You were a miner then.
Since the age of thirteen, yes, at the Newcastle mines. Fifteen years of hell. Those were bloody times...
But now it's over. I don't want to die in those holes like my father and my brothers did, in order to line the pockets of the rich... "coughing"
You'd better behave! Your alibi is pretty weak so no need to pretend!
It's no aliby! It's the truth. But you surely don't care!
Small people such as us are eternal victims of "cough" a corrupted justice.
I won't speak anymore.
AlternativeAlibiText
Hmm...
Interesting...
Good day, Lestrade. Seems you are in a bad mood. Another tricky case?
You don't need your deductive method to find that out.
So what exactly happened?
Are you joking, mister Holmes? It's already in all newspapers! The priceless pictures were stolen from the exhibition hall this night!
What have you found already?
J. Fundes, the janitor,  is a prime suspect. He's currently hiding somewhere in Oldgrove. It's all in the report.
I can't see you that upset, my friend. Guess I'll spare my five-o-clock and get this thief for you.
Have you found the thief? Whom should I arrest?
The smoking woman is the one you seek.
I guess the one I pursued could be a woman as well... Thank you.
Just give me a minute to check my conclusions...
Sure, mister Holmes, I'll wait as long as needed.
Got her, mister Holmes. And the wallet she was hiding! Many thanks for your help!
You are welcome, Donovan. But you definitely should learn to do this without my help.
Oh, mister Holmes, that was a disaster! Not only I got into a fight trying to grab the suspect, but there was no wallet with him!
Seems you let the thief escape, Donovan. Are you sure he had no companions here?
Companions... Oh, and they took the wallet and sneaked away in the fight? That must be so! I'm taking the guy to police station and we'll have the answers there!
See you later, Lestrade.
We met with Jerryl. He didn't like it, though.
Where is he?
Rests in his house, waiting for your men to get him to the prison hospital. Here's the address. I doubt he'll leave until you come.
It's great news! I'll sent my men there immediately!
I found the place where your thief was, Lestrade, but we haven't met.
Where is it? We'll make a trap there, maybe he'll return?
Don't bother your men, Lestrade. You can get him on board of the ship "Agia Marina".
The one leaving tomorrow? My best men will be waiting for him then.
Before you gather your men, you should know some things about Fundes.
He's armed, got a revolver. Shaved off his moustache, but maybe will put on a fake beard. And the pictures were cut off the frames - he'll hide them in his luggage.
Oh, that's a valuable info! I'll instruct my men about that.
Ah, sir! It seems I am a lucky man, a lucky man indeed!
How so, mister...?
Archer. Mr. Donovan Archer. You see, mister, this beautiful gold watch is mine
It means so much to me. I am so glad you found them
You can have it, sir. Makes no difference to me.
Thank you! You are a most wise and discerning man.
A treasured possession you've neglected to repair after it stopped?
Fine! There really is no fooling you, is there...
And a wedding gift, with a date like that! You don't look more than 40 to me.
You see, mister, I've been through quite an adventure recently, and I am afraid many of my things suffered from it.
Mr. Archer, this watch seems to be a bit neglected. Are you sure it's a treasured possession you are looking for?
Please, this watch is all that remains of my late wife. She had it specially manufactured for our wedding.
Ah, sir! It seems I am a lucky man, a lucky man indeed!
How so, mister...?
Archer. Mr. Donovan Archer. You see, mister, this beautiful gold watch is a treasured possesion of mine.
My late wife had it crafted for our wedding anniversary. Please, I would like to have them back.
I don't believe you, sir. No need to dig yourself deeper - I'm keeping the watch, and there is that.
You took my watch and call me a liar?! Fine! Just wait for the policeman to arrest you for stealing precious property!
The date on this watch suggests your marriage is rather ancient.
Uh... it's a replica of my family's lost heirloom! A very special wedding gift, you see. My wife is so considerate!
The watch looks properly expensive for a well-dressed gentleman like you. You may have it.
Thank you! You are a most wise and discerning man.
Hey, give me that back this instant, you knave! Do you have any idea how much that thing is worth?!
It's the only inheritance I have! You can't take away this last bit of my family!
The only way a man like you could afford a watch this expensive is by inheriting it. Have it back.
Thank you! I know I don't look like much, but this watch is the most precious thing I have.
Which is why you shouldn't pawn it. Isn't that where you were headed?
I... you are right. Thank you, sir.
Somehow I don't believe you. I'm keeping the watch.
No! That's the only memory I have from my... You're dead, you hear me?!
Good day, miss. Looking for someone?
I'm Emily Essent. My father, Nicholas, is missing for more than a day and I'm afraid he's got into trouble!
May I offer you my help, miss? My name is Sherlock Holmes, I'm a detective.
Oh sir, please find him!
Old man is in his silly treasure pursuit again! I asked police to help, but they refused! I tried to find him myself... I don't know what to do!
Can you please describe your father?
He's in his sixties, short and thin... Grey hair, thick glasses. He is obsessed with urban legends and treasure hunting!
Do you have any ideas where he could be?
I've no ideas now. Checked the library and archives already... and even local pubs! God knows where his obsession could drive him!
You mentioned your father's obsession. May I ask you to be more detailed?
He spents days gathering local legends and sinks into the archives. All his study is piled with old maps, notes and dusty tomes!
But what's worse, my father digs in the places no sane man dares to visit! Old mines, catacombs, even sewers! That's why I'm so worried...
I will help you, but can I see his room first? Maybe I'll find something that'll shed a light on his whereabouts.
Please be our guest. His room is upstairs, in the end of the corridor.
What's your take on the events?
I don't know, Mr. Holmes, I don't even know. This is a nightmare!
Did he have any enemies? Anyone that could have done it?
He was young, rich and so, so good-natured, of course he had enemies! But this is beyond their admittedly negligible caliber.
So grotesque, so morbidly... artistic. I know no one who could conceive something like this.
Your testimony is invaluable. Goodbye.
Hello again, Mr. Nero. How are you holding up?
Oh, I'm surviving. I'm lucky to have dear Ann here with me.
You mean your maid?
Indeed. Charming little creature. Not a malicious bone in her body. And believe you me, I've looked.
Ahem.
It's been so terribly stressful in the last few weeks, and now with Dougal's death...
I have to get my mind off it somehow so it doesn't snap like a twig.
I will take all this into consideration. Goodbye.
What the... who the hell are you? How did you get here?
Sherlock Holmes. I'm looking for mister Nicholas Essent.
Your search is over. My mercy reserves finished with the old man. Prepare to meet your maker!
I didn't want to hurt you, but you leave me no choice.
The volunteers are searching the sewers, looking for the lost old man. Many people gathered after his daughter asked for help.
I will help him to get home. Thank you for helping him.
And don't forget to tell others you found him! Allright, boys, we leave for now.
Oh, oh, thank you, mister. Those jentleman were quite... persuasive. But... who are you?
My name is Sherlock. Your daughter asked me to find you. Are you okay?
I'll be fine, don't worry. Those fools... they don't even believe in the guardian of the treasure!
You mean the thing that the legend tells about? Do you believe in it?
Old legends may sound weird, but there is always some truth behind them.
Let's leave the place. We have to get you home.
There is another tunnel near the barrels. We can use it.
Mary Elizabeth? I'm Sherlock Holmes. Enchanted to meet you.
Leave! Run before the spirits pick you as the next target!
You'll have to explain the "spirits" bit.
Lieutenant, restrain the lady before anybody is hurt.
No, you can't!
The dead have come for my brother, and now they threaten the whole island! But I can stop them.
How would you do that?
I have the power over them now. You must let me finish the invocation!
Fine, you may proceed, but I need to see the crime scene.
At your own peril!
Yes yes, I'm terrified.
My brother is in his room upstairs. But be wary - the vengeful spirits are still about him!
Did your brother gamble? I found a casino chip stuck in his mouth.
Oh, the poor wretch! I did know he had room for gambling among his many, many sins!
That's why the dead were able to find him so easily. They just had to follow the stench of his rotten soul.
Do you suspect anyone?
I can't think of anyone. You'd have a hard time finding an enemy of Dougal McDonagh on the entire island.
Would you explain the strange paraphernalia in your room?
It's the special gift I have. I see many worlds, not just the one we're in right now. And I need the tools to access it.
You need to find a better use for your time.
Even now that my brother lies dead, strangled by a risen deadman, you would say something like that?
Whatever you say.
We should talk once this is all over. You have a very strong aura.
Tell me something I don't know.
I will be back if I have more questions.
Help, please! Stop them!
What happened to you, mister? A robbery?
It's all my fault! They took the box with bottles, thought it was just booze! Stop them, please!
You mean there is something else than alcohol in your bottles.
I'm an artist, James Mann, I have a studio in this district. And the robber took the wood-spirit I use to solve the varnish! He'll die if he drinks it!
How do they look like?
One of them has horrible scars. The other two are usual drunkards, one wearing a red shirt and the other - an old dirty coat.
Where did the robbers go after beating you?
Down the street towards the church.
You are so worried - why? Those robbers has beaten you, took your property. Maybe not for the first time. Why don't leave them to their fate?
Poor lost souls, they don't deserve to be poisoned! Perhaps they have families, children... It's all my fault, I had to hide the bottles better!
I was weak and could not escape, and I could not even warn them after a single punch... Please, mister, have mercy, save this men!
You truly are a kind soul. I'll stop them and bring you back your dangerous bottle.
Mr. Holmes, I need your help! There's been a murder! A butcher's apprentice, Moe Deegan, has been killed.
We've got two suspects, butcher Pete Milligan and juggler Franko. Need your eye for detail to solve this one!
What can you tell me about the butcher?
The victim was his employee. Other than that, I got nothing.
What about the juggler?
He spent the whole day around this area, ended up within the lockdown. Plus look at all the knives!
I'll see what I can do.
The butcher is your man. He didn't butcher any pigs today - only his own apprentice. The only bloodied apron here is on the victim.
I knew it! Well, not really - I thought for sure the damn juggler was the guilty one. I owe him an apology. Thanks, Mr. Holmes!
The clues all point to the butcher.
I will trust your judgment, Mr. Holmes. Thank you.
The clues point towards the juggler.
I will trust your judgment, Mr. Holmes. Thank you.
Greetings, officer, your backup has arrived. Let me through.
I wasn't informed of any backup...
But you were, just now. Now let me inspect the scene - perhaps the traces are still hot.
I already did. This is an arson, the criminal smashed the window and threw something burning inside.
Something? That's not an explanation at all.
I doubt you'll find more.
I've inspected the crime scene and found out an important detail.
And so? Write about it in the report.
It's the missing box that was taken by someone after the fire was stopped. Do you think I have to report about it?
The box? What are you talking about? There were no boxes on the table!
It may contain important evidence - or else why the culprit or his henchman would steal it? Any investigator would take this obvious lead.
You think so?...
Definitely. It's up to you to decide whom to tell where it is now - to me or to the Lt. Placido.
Please... my children... There is no future for them on this island! You must understand! that's the only chance for them to have a good education and leave Gollanza!
I'll think about this situation when I'll see the box.
It's behind the house, hidden near the fence. Take what you want, but don't tell Placido! Don't you know about our life here? Won't you pick up such a chance yourself?
Rich pimps won't even feel this loss! Maybe they left the island already! You want these things to rot in the police safe to be "lost" after a year or two? Why?
Don't make a fuss, man. We'll share the loot to the mutual profit. The thief is dead and no one can tell where he was hiding the goods.
Oh... Phew... I thought you are some crazy saint willing to lose a chance for better life for nothing...
So, what's your take on all this?
Bah! Of course it was the butcher! Everybody knows the poor kid was screwing his wife.
Everybody?
Really, it's surprising the old man only did something about it now.
Your knives are identical to the murder weapon. Any way you can explain it?
So that's where it went! Someone stole it from me this morning! I spent hours looking for it.
Bah. I don't suppose I can get it back now, can I?
That's all for now. Don't go anywhere.
Are you sure that's all you know?
Sure I am sure! Just surprised that fat prick only did it now.
So, what's your take on all this?
It's that bloody juggler! He and Moe had a fight over a gambling debt a few days ago.
Still, I never thought the bloody reprobate would stoop to murder!
What were you doing at the time of murder?
That's no secret. I was at the shop, preparing the meat. You have to do it at sunrise, you know.
If you were butchering pigs, why is your apron clean?
Uhm... I was mostly directing Moe. He was my apprentice after all, he, uh... learned by doing.
As a butcher, you'd know anatomy fairly well - in your line of work efficiency is key.
That's true. I'd make a professional out of Moe too if that filthy juggler hadn't gotten him!
Yes, the juggler... Now, if we could establish how he was able to inflict such a clean and deadly strike.
Huh... Oh, you know the circus crowd, always with tricks up their sleeves!
Are you sure that's all you know?
Of course I am! Will it take much longer? It's obvious that circus freak did it!
That's all for now. Don't go anywhere just yet.
Do you recognize the man in this picture?
Why would I? And besides, I have a lot of work to do, leave me alone.
What's a golden tooth worth in a pawn shop nowadays?
What are you talking about?!
Someone has been robbing graves in your cemetery, mostly old ones - and one recent. Which might be connected to a recent murder.
Oh, blast it. You work for the police?
I am, so it's best you cooperate.
The other way around, not that it changes anything. Tell me the truth.
Fine, maybe I did go digging once in a while, but only the older ones!
So who's the recent burial? Is this his photo?
Good God, that's Jeremiah White! Sir, I have no idea who got him.
Can I see the letter?
Sorry, I... got rid of it. So much money and no signature - it's nothing but trouble.
Your testimony is invaluable. Goodbye.
label
label
Good day, miss. I'm assuming you're Mr. Nero's maid?
Yes, sir, name's Ann! Master Nero was so kind to have hired me.
What's your opinion on Giovanni?
Oh, he's out of this world. Were it not for him, I'd have nowhere to say, no way to support myself. And he can be so charming...
Thank you for your time. Goodbye.
Let's get serious, Miss Walsh - or Miss White, if you so prefer. I know you killed Dougal.
Ugh. Do you now. So what next?
The sedative in your room. You drugged Dougal so he wouldn't resist.
Ungh. He wouldn't put up much of a fight anyway, but I had to be sure.
Why did you desecrate your father's remains like that?
It's Giovanni. He was next. Wanted to give him a proper scare before his time came.
Nothing to be proud of, but my father was gone all the same. They made an addict of him and took him from me.
Your crime cannot go unpunished. The police shall decide your fate.
Oh good, and so Giovanni will be free to continue his work. If this is what you call justice, choke on it.
Leave the island. Immediately.
What do you mean?
I cannot sympathize with your motives, but I do empathize. There has been enough bloodshed - leave and let the police handle Giovanni.
I... I will, Mr. Holmes.
What do you need, buddy? Don't you see we are busy here?
I noticed the familiar box with bottles here. Isn't it from the local artist?
He made a donation. And who are you to ask? Looking for trouble?
There is a wood-spirit in this bottles, not the booze. It will leave you blind or dead after a few gulps.
Why should I believe you? How do you know?
The owner of the box told me about it. He pleaded to find you and stop from poisoning yourself.
Do you think we are imbeciles? You expect me to believe the guy I punched in the face sent you to save us?
Because I sold him the box. Listen, pals, I don't care if you don't believe, but warning you is something a good man should do.
Crap! What shall we drink now? Hey, mister good man, maybe you tell us?
Look, I can buy the box from you. It will be enough to have an evening in a good pub, not among the graves.
What's in it for you? Maybe we can just take your money, huh? But... fine, let's have a deal.
I'm here to take the box back to the owner. Give it here, now, and we'll pass the part with violence.
"Pass the part", you say? No way!
Come on, boys! Let's teach him a lesson!
I'm Sherlock Holmes, consulting detective. Please, tell me what you saw.
Two men just jumped out and started firing. Donaldson was killed but I managed to get out of the car in time and the gunfire started.
I shot one of them - he's lying over there. But then I was wounded and lost my counsciousness. When I woke up, the gold was missing.
Can you describe the second man?
A man of average build, dark hair, dressed in leather jacket... I don't remember anything else. Everything happened so fast.
Are you sure about this description? The weight of stolen gold is too big for one robber of average build.
I could make a mistake - the first robber was shooting at me at the same moment. But I'm sure about the leather jacket.
That will be all for now. Thank you.
Yes?
I noticed that your shoes are stained. Can you explain how the slime from the sewers appeared on them?
What? I... I have no idea. I was unconscious.
This dirt means that you were at sewers. You knew where the gold was all this time! Why didn't you tell this?
Uh! Okay, okay. I understood that the robbers hid the gold there. I just wanted to bring it back by myself. I wanted to be a hero.
I'm sorry.
I examined the dead robber. He was shot from behind and it was almost a point blank. This doesn't fit your testimony.
It was a gunfight! Anything could happen. Besides, I'm wounded, I could make a little mistake.
Thank you, that is all for now.
Crutch.
Good day, mister. I apologize for unconviniency, but we are closed.
I received a letter from Mr. Kaltes this morning. My name is Sherlock Holmes.
Mister Holmes! I'm Jeffrey Cooper. Was instructed to give you any needed assistance! Just let me know what do you need.
A few questions before I start.
I must see the room of the victim. Where is it?
On the second floor, room 105. It is locked though, but officer Callebini has a key.
The cook, Andrea - what can you tell about him?
Worked here for many years. Got a sharp tongue, but never went further than curses. Cooking is an art for him, I think. All this poisoning is not a thing I can believe in.
Thank you.
I will be here in case you need something else.
Jeffrey, are there any notes about the clients food orders? Something more than the kitchen tickets like this one?
There is a journal of orders in the kitchen. The cook receives an order from the waiter and notes it there. When the dish is ready, it is left for a waiter with a ticket.
I'd like to see those notes.
Sure, Mr Holmes, the kitchen is behind the bar stand. You'll find the journal of food orders there.
I'm afraid I can't help you with this. Our hotel guarantees the privacy of the customers.
Tell me about the room 203. Who lives there now?
Mr Mateo Borini, one of the actors of the Cantini theater.
Firelli's double? I need access to this room!
Could it be that you lost the key from this room while counting money?
What money?
All those shiny sovereigns some unattentive guest dropped here.
Oh, I see. Of course that's my duty to gather them and to return to the owner. And this key from the room on the third floor could fall from my pocket in the process...
Fine, I respect your rules. But can you tell if this guest is at home now?
Mr Borini went to the theater. Should not come back before the afternoon.
That's all I need to know.
The owner of the hotel, Darrel Kaltes, asked me to investigate the murder of the actor, Firelli.
And what do you think about it?
You were right about the cook. Only he had a way to poison Firelli.
Did you have any doubt? We know our work, Mr Holmes!
I can prove that Andrea is innocent. The man who poisoned Firelli was his double, Mateo.
What? Why could he do this?
He was going to take Firelli's place in the theater. Firelli was not expecting anything dangerous from him. He used Mateo as a double not only in the theater, but also when he was ill or drugged.
He ordered some canapes to his room before going down, put the allergen in them and gave to Firelli. After that Borini went down in Firelli's outfit, ate the supper and pretended to feel sick.
But if Borini was here, how could he poison Firelli?
We should hurry to arrest him! Thank you for your help, Mr Holmes!
Good day, officer. I'm here to investigate Firelli's death. Can I ask you a few questions?
Old Darrel doesn't believe his cook to be the murderer, does he? As for me the situation is clear.
Andrea was mad with the singer criticizing his dishes and poisoned him. You may look around, if you want, but that's a waste of time.
Is Andrea still here? Can I talk to him?
No, we took him to the prison. But I have the testimonies with me. Want to see them?
If it's possible.
I want to see the crime scene and the body. Can you show me the place?
The body was taken to the morgue, but you can read the autopsy report. The room where Firelli was found is on the second floor.
What about the autopsy results?
Just a second... wait... oh, it seems I left them  somewhere on the crime scene...
It happens. I'll find it myself then.
Bring them back after you finish, ok?
See you later, officer.
I'll be here for a few hours more. Don't forget to return my papers.
Let me think...
How fortunate that you're here, Mr. Holmes! We have a robber that somehow managed to steal 120 kilos of gold by himself.
Are you interested in this case?
The key to a sharp mind is constant training. I'll solve it in no time.
I'm sure you'll handle this without me. Maybe another time.
As you say, Mr. Holmes. If you need something, just ask me.
The gold was not so far as you could think, officer. I found it in the nearest sewer.
You're amazing, Mr. Holmes! Now we have one less thing to find - the robber.
Officer, did someone move this truck?
Nothing was moved since the police is here.
Move the car, please. I want to take a look what's under it.
Just wait a minute.
Officer, one of the culprits survived and escaped. Better to start looking for him, he couldn't go far.
Understood, Mr. Holmes. We'll start searching for him immediately.
Thank you for your help.
Mr. Holmes?
I'm afraid, the second robber is Mr. Grasso, the witness.
But why you think so?!
His testimony is contradictional. Besides, the slime on his shoes says that he knew where the gold was hidden.
Unbelievable... You're brilliant as always, Mr. Holmes. Thank you.
Sorry, I need some time to think about all this.
Sure.
Thank you, that is all for now.
Hm...
I see...
Let me think for a bit.
Wait a moment...
Interesting...
Holmes, what is the meaning of this? I thought the house was on fire!
Excuse me?
What do you smoke, Lieutenant Placido?
There you are, Lieutenant.
Uhm... "I Granatieri", why?
You heard me. What do you smoke?
I've been testing local cigarette brands all day, and could still smell you coming from all the way across the police station.
Note to self - "I Granatieri" are the strongest after all.
Nevermind, I've been studying the local cigarette brands. What have you brought me?
I see. We have a situation, Holmes. A charity firm owner has been murdered-
Try again, with a touch of excitement.
...By a dead man. There's another cadaver on top of our cadaver, gripping the fellow's throat.
Dead men walking! Solving that shouldn't be too hard.
Don't tell me you've figured it out already.
I already have a solid lead - dead men don't walk by themselves.
Sorry, this doesn't sound much more exciting than my leisure already is.
Ugh. I hope you reconsider, Holmes.
Tell me everything you know so far.
Two bodies, one anonymous, one Dougal McDonagh, the master of the house. Rich, respected, ran a charity. Sounds like a nice fellow.
I suppose even nice fellows aren't safe from something like this.
His sister found him dead in his bed, with the other corpse strangling him. You should take a look for yourself.
Tell me everything you know so far.
Two bodies, one anonymous, one Dougal McDonagh, the master of the house. I have his profile right here.
His sister found him dead in his bed, with the other corpse strangling him. You should take a look for yourself.
I will have to converse with the sister. What do you know so far?
Mary Elizabeth McDonagh, unmarried, and at her age she ought to be. People say she's an odd case.
Never to her face though, nor to Mr. McDonagh's.
What was it about a charity?
"Heart of Gold", small firm, big impact. Mostly art patronage.
I will see what I can find.
Good! I'll be taking Miss McDonagh in. Her motive is plastered all over her room.
I have some leads, my investigation will continue elsewhere. You may take over.
Holmes, where are you going?
That's a motive - nothing more. Leave a man to watch over the house, but don't give the lady an undue scare.
Fine, I will have someone stick around. But it's your head if she tries anything!
Might be wise, but make no convictions until we have proof.
I know how to do my job.
You'll hear from me when I find something solid.
Has the philantropist's murder been solved already?
No, Holmes. You can still help.
Goodbye, officer.
I have a conclusion that the shop owner is an actual robber. The case is solved.
That's an unexpexted finding, Mr. Holmes. Did you found evidences of that?
This letter about the debt and the fact that the stolen books were burned. As I remember they were insured.
This makes sense. Thank you, Mr. Holmes. We'll deal with everything else.
Extraordinary as always, Mr. Holmes!
You can find the robber in the tunnel under the bank of Gollanza. And here's the remaining stolen book, others, I'm afraid, were burned.
And don't forget to warn the bank guards about the new entrance to their building - the tunnel made by the thieves.
As you say. Thank you for your help.
Oh, good day, inspector Calebbini. I guess you already know what happened here.
Most of it, mister Holmes. Two armed bastards tried to rob the bank. We came as fast as we could and shot one, but the second escaped.
But the banker outside told he's still here.
We searched all the building and found nothing. That's some devilry, that's what I say. He could not get out of the basement, but he's not there.
Mind if I take a look?
Please do. Maybe you'll guess where his magic trick took him.
I have a theory about the missing robber, but for checking it I have to open one of the safes.
We have to ask Mr.Borelli to do this. He has the keys and the passwords. But why should we do this?
You'll see when it's done. And prepare your gun, just in case.
Officer Lyonelli! I know who is guilty in Norman Brown's death.
And you've got the proofs? Tell me then. I promise to take your thought into consideration.
I think Basilio Copello is the murderer.
That's our main version, yes. But maybe you found something we don't know?
Well, they were enemies, had a business rivalry. Basilio changed the safe lock combination and closed his enemy inside.
That sounds odd, but even stranger things happen. I want to arrest the night watchman, he has to know what happened in the office. Thank you for your assistance, Mr Holmes.
I think the night watch, William Lloyd, is a murderer.
He's very suspicious indeed. But do you have proofs?
I think he has some kind of mental disorder. So when Norman and the other man sneaked into the office and tried to steal some documents, William attacked them.
I know Norman Brown well, and your guess is believable. But what was he stealing?
The papers that could turn the court on his side. So, William scared off Norman's accomplice and beat Norman hard. Then he threw him in the safe.
He was sitting near it with a stethoscope and listened to his victim's suffering, smoking his cigarettes. I found both the stethoscope, its traces and the cig butt.
My God, what a monster! I'll send men to arrest him immediately!
I found the guilty man. You know him, it's Felix Sevigne, a safecracker.
Felix Screw-Up? I know this bastard! But how it happened?
Norman Brown hired him to steal the documents to win the lawsuit against Copello. They sneaked into the office and tried to open the safe.
But how did he end up in the safe?!
When they opened the door and found nothing, Norman swore loudly and the night watchman came to see.
Felix fled through the balcony, but Norman prefered to hide in the safe and locked himself accidentally. Felix didn't care to free him and Norman died.
So that's mostly an accident during the crime. What a moral story it is! Of course, Felix is guilty, but not that much.  We'll accuse him of burglary and leaving the man in danger!
They had a quarrel and a fight after Felix opened the empty safe. Felix knocked Norman out and stuck him in the safe. Then the night watch came.
That could be the case! I'll order my men to double the efforts and catch the Screw-Up as soon as they can!
Let them start from the Vagabond's Haven bar.
Many thanks for your help, Mr Holmes! You've assisted the police greatly!
Norman's death is mostly accidental, but Augusta Copello was the reason he died.
I have to do something about it but in a most delicate manner possible. Augusta is not that guilty, but it is for the court to decide...
Norman and Augusta had a love affair. They met in the office late in the evening. That day Basilio came suddenly to take Augusta home.
And Norman was hiding in the safe? But everyone knew the combination...
Basilio changed it before selling the safe. So Augusta could not let her lover out. She hurried to find a safecracker and brought Felix Sevigne later.
What? How come?
So Norman died because she didn't ask Basilio about the combination?
She was in despair, panicked and made a mistake. I was just in time to save her from the second one.
What do you mean?
She tried to commit suicide. She's not that guilty, but the law is the law.
He opened the safe, but it was too late. Augusta screamed and the night watchman came, scaring Felix off. So she has to close the safe and pretend that she knows nothing.
Hello, Lieutenant. I've seen the scene - you were right to call for me.
Thank goodness you're here, Holmes? Do we have a new Jack the Ripper on our hands?
That could be a possibility. Even this wonderful ocean air cannot heal a damaged mind.
Oh no, that adventure is in the past. We're dealing with something new entirely.
You have to help us! We've never dealt with such savagery. I've put many criminals behind bars, but those were just men.
Who is the victim?
Safiye Barak, a lokum seller. Dio santo, I remember buying from her when I was a beat cop.
Do we have any suspects yet?
Go soft on the man if you question him. It's anybody's guess what he's going through.
Only the master of the house. The victim is his wife, she was home alone with their daughter at the time.
Do we have any witnesses?
None. The shop was closed, so no buyers, and the victim's daughter slept through the whole event.
I will be back should I need your help.
I found this on the scene. A letter with overt threats.
Let me see that! Huh. It's not signed.
Indeed, how dare the killer make it so hard for us.
Quit it, Holmes, there's no call for it. If you have any idea what this means, follow it! Just don't play hero.
It was Rade Zoric, the neighbour. Mrs. Barak bought medicine from him and got into debts.
When she couldn't pay, he made an example of her for others.
Buon Dio. Just when you think you've seen true depravity the next case manages to up the ante.
We'll take over from here, Holmes. Thanks for living up to your fame.
I know the killer. It was the daughter.
Come again?
It was their daughter. She has mental issues, and the mother found no better option to combat them than to start sedating her.
That sort of sedative is used to treat violent patients. Little Melisa seems to be just that.
Buon Dio. Not sure there was any way to prepare for this.
Hello, Lieutenant. What's our situation?
Finally! Holmes, it's a bloodbath in here. See for yourself, then come back.
The killer has given us a slip, but rest assured - I'm handling the matter.
What's that supposed to mean? You're a civilian, going after that... fiend!
Need I remind you of other fiends I've already caught? Meanwhile, I believe it's time to let the Baraks have some peace.
If you're sure. Thank you, Holmes. I must admit, you're saving me some grey hair.
I'm looking for Swanny. Is he here?
Maybe he is, maybe not. Who's asking?
Sherlock Holmes. Mrs. Hudsonini told you can't leave because your friend needs help, and you are noisy.
Oh, you are that Holmes! I heard about you!
You can tell me what happened. The sooner we deal with your problem, the better.
We got driven from our shelter. I sent Pickles to the forlorn crockery factory to check the place.  Something happened there, but we don't know what!
He returned later, pale and trembling, mumbling nonsense. Pickles is so sick now and we can't just bring him to the doctor!
The boy - can you tell me about him? His habits, temper, that sort of things. There is something why you sent him, not someone else.
No, no, it's just to punish him for eating most of our supplies. Pickles is always hungry as a shark! Eats anything he can chew.
Please tell me where this factory is, Swanny. I'm not a local.
It's the forlorn crockery factory in front of the D.Reef hotel. You'll find it easily if you walk down the street that starts from the church doors.
Fine. I'll find out what happened there.
Show me what Pickles brought from the factory.
There's a bag near him. We didn't touch anything. What happened?
I'll tell after I inspect his things.
You are back! You found what happened?
There were some old drugs on the factory. Pickles tasted some and poisoned himself.
Oh gosh... What should we do?
Pickles found the box of the outdated tinned food on the factory. I found one opened.
He ate them? Oh, why do I ask? Of course he did! What should we do now?
Pickles found a lot of mushrooms on the factory. He thought them to be edible and ate some because of hunger.
Stupid dumbass! Are these mushrooms poisonous?
Don't you see they are? Your friend needs a real medic and the sooner the better!
But we have no money! What should we do?!
They are hallucinogenes, but your friend will be fine. Let him drink as much as he can and rest.
Bring him to the doctor. I'll pay for the treatment.
But we won't return such a debt...
We'll talk about this when Pickles will be fine.
Thank you, Mr Holmes! We'll be eager to help if needed!
Find them or pray and hope for the best.
We'll try to. Thank you, mister.
Good day, sir. I'm investigating your boss's murder.
Ah, good day! I'll help you anyway I can. Name's Charlie.
Does the name Jeremiah White ring a bell?
Hm. No, should it?
He was a beneficiary.
Ah. You know how many of those we got?
I need to figure out why Jeremiah White had turned up at Dougal McDonagh's scene of death. What's the connection?
Goodness, I've no idea!
What can you tell me about Dougal, your boss?
Eh, he paid us well. Never said hello to anyone, but I didn't come here for that, did I?
Didn't deserve to die in my book, but... he he... It's a good thing we have another one.
Another Dougal McDonagh?
Nah, another boss! He co-owned the company. It's Mr. Giovanni Nero who made it in the first place.
We hardly see him around here though. Makes him all the better a boss if you ask me.
I'll find those responsible.
This building looks bigger on the outside.
Can't help you with that, sir.
Bye.
The painter does not seem to be feeling well.
Bah. Have you ever seen a healthy painter? Besides, he seems good enough at his job. Leave him be.
He mentioned a chip.
That's for beneficiaries only, and you're too well-dressed for a starving artist.
Dead? Oh, that is a marvellous idea! That's what I shall draw next. Dougal McDonagh in the clutches of eternal slumber!
The man you're paiting so vigoriously... you know he's dead, right?
But only after I draw master Giovanni once more.
I'd... hate to interrupt you then. Go on.
Who is master Giovanni?
The best, kindest man in the world, now that master Dougal is gone! If I do well, they'll give me a chip!
A chip like this one?
Oh my! I wonder what you have done to prove yourself. Go on then! I still need to earn mine!
Stop, mister! It's dangerous to go in!
Someone attempted to rob your bank?
Yes! One of them is killed, but the police can't find the other! Those fools only tell nonsence about magic!
I'm Sherlock Holmes, the detective from London. If I find the robber, will you cash out my cheque without delay?
I'll double the sum, mister Holmes! Just don't let this bastard to escape justice!
I checked the bank and I know where is your robber.
Impressive indeed! And where is he?
I think your robber could sneak out and escape.
But the police searched the building!
He could hide near the ladder and get away while they ran deeper in.
If it happened as you say, this is a total incompetence of the police! I will have a talk with the bank owners about this incident!
I doubt you want to stay here long, so please tell me about the murder you are accused of.
This is madness! I wanted to sell this damned safe! Invited the customer, opened it... to show it from inside... and he was there... dead...
You seem to be very stressed, Mr Copello. Let's go slow - I'll ask, you'll answer.
Here you are, Mr Copello. My name is Sherlock Holmes, I received your letter today.
So, you opened the safe to show it to the customer and found a man there. Do you know him?
I... no, I didn't... didn't know him personally.
You are hesitating to answer.
I know who he is, everybody knows. His father, Douglas Brown, is one of the most prosperous landlords of the island. Norman is... was his son.
I guess your safe once belonged to a bank. Who could open it?
Yes, I bought the office with it. The safe stood open most of the time. Everyone knew the combination!
Weren't you keeping anything of value inside?
Only the old papers.
I have to see the place myself. Can you explain to me, how to get to the "Copello Co" office from here?
Yes, yes. Let me show you.
I think you don't tell me everything. You knew Norman Brown quite well - at least you met in the court.
Still, it's not... Well, yes, I knew him better than I'd like to. We had some business... controversion. But I didn't kill him!
It would be stupid to hide him in the safe and to show to the customer then! I'm not that mad.
Keep calm, Mr Copello. I'll find out the truth.
Ehm, sorry but I don't understand...
I have more questions, Mr Copello.
I think that's enough for now. Goodbye, Mr Copello.
You have some troubles in your family life, don't you?
What? No, everything is fine! I love Augusta! Why do you even ask?
Your pocket watch is cleaned in a strange way. Everything is shining, except the inscription.
Huh... I usually ask Augusta to clean it. Never noticed it before.
Don't worry. Perhaps she's afraid to spoil the engraving.
Greetings, ma'am. Sherlock Holmes, at your service. I believe you had found something recently?
Changelings, Mr. Holmes! Veritable changelings. Small, green like frogs, and don't speak a lick of English.
And before you ask, when I brought them home I gave both a good scrubbing, but the green stayed!
Where exactly did you find them?
Out on the Greentmantle Bogs. I go there to collect herbs. Me mother was a healer, taught me which ones to pick.
When did you find these changelings?
A couple of days ago. I cleaned them up and let them sleep under me roof. Fairies or not, ain't no such thing as "other people's children".
Can I take a look at them?
Of course. But if you speak English, they'll just warble at you in their sweet fairie tongue.
Thank you. I will be back if I need anything.
For the Fair Folk I'd say this is too far from home.
Nonsense. I leave offerings for the Tuatha De Danann every day! And they watch over me in return, now that I'm... was alone.
Have you lost a child, Miss Philipps?
Ah! But how did you...
You obviously care for the ones you found, then there's you being a foreigner living here alone.
I surmise you lost your child and your husband to the same event.
You're... you're correct of course, Mr. Holmes. I couldn't turn my back on these children, however they came to be on that bog.
Does the police know you've found two children out on the bogs?
What does the island's police have to do with this? These are changelings, they're not of this land. Not of this world even.
Still, they might have worried parents looking for them.
Bah, the police would just give them to that circus crook D'Agostino! He's been asking about green children all over the town.
I have news, Miss Philipps. The children are likely escaped slaves...
Oh golly!
It's likely the reason they are... socially stunted. There is a nasty illegal mine out on the bogs, but it's being dealt with.
I had no idea. They weren't changelings after all! Good lord, no child should ever have so much misery in their lives.
But tell me, what gave them the green hue?
I believe it's copper. Other people in the copper mine also had stained skin.
The water in the cave they were kept in was green as well. I believe it was contaminated with something.
I think it's cave mushrooms. Their entire diet consisted of those for years upon years.
Golly! I will have to watch their health carefully. I know just the right herbs.
One more thing, Miss Philipps.
I think the children should stay with you. This household deserves to be a little louder and happier.
Thank you for your kind words, Mr. Holmes. Noone will ever harm them again.
You're welcome to join us for dinner any time. I finally have someone to bake pies for!
The children should be taken by the state. Two lives are a big responsibility.
But Mr. Holmes, I'm willing to take it! They'll just send them to an orphanage otherwise!
Do not take this personally. I only wish to ensure they get proper help.
Help? An orphanage is no place for children. Any children, let alone those who are loved.
Perhaps there's another way of looking at this.
I've talked with the circus ringleader. He thinks your "changelings" might have a future with him.
Oh, how could you say that! They are children, not trick ponies!
They may not adapt to normal life, Miss Philipps. And in the circus they'll be accepted - and make their own money.
Make money by demeaning themselves! I expected better of you.
Sen Turkce konusmayi biliyor musun?
Beszelsz magyarul?
Sprichst du Deutsch?
Dagvekhmare! Mama k'vlav mghvimeshia!
Nothing I know seems to check out.
Greetings, young man. May I ask your name?
Eh? Ser, chven gamovedit mghvimeshi!
Now that's unusual.
Hello, sir, I'm Sherlock Holmes, investigating the two changelings a local farmer found. I heard you've been looking for them?
Bah, changelings! Is that what she called them? They're the stars of my lineup! I am Gianluigi D'Agostino, the master of ceremonies.
Members of a hidden tribe from the deepest, most secret Africa. There is no mistaking their green skin.
How come they're green?
That's the mystery, isn't it? I am no expert, but I have a theory.
It's something about their land. Everything is green that deep in Africa. The apes, the cats, even the rivers! Maybe it's the air?
They don't seem to speak or understand a word of English.
What did you expect? Sun may never set on the British Empire, but that deep into Africa, they haven't even heard about England.
There are more things out there, Mr. Holmes, than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
Actually,
Oh! Huh.
I do
Ha ha
Give me
That's odd
Just one last thing I wanted to ask.
Shoot!
Huh. Can't think of anything after all.
How come your star performers are so malnourished?
Wait, what?
I've seen those children. Either you're lying about them being your stars, or you've been starving them.
I can imagine that's an essential skill if you're gonna profit off a freakshow.
They can be cruel that way.
Not to mention the profits. And make no mistake, I'm an honest entrepreneur. Bring them to me, and you'll get a cut too.
A bribe then!
Please. Finder's fee.
Come think about it, they are a bit of an oddity. I'll talk to Miss Philipps about it.
Neither of you two will regret it, Holmes! I'll make stars of those children yet!
Argh! Son of a...
Watch yourself, ringleader. I don't believe your good intentions for a moment.
This is no simple matter. I will return.
Think it over, Holmes. Think it over.
The office is clo... sorry, officer. Others are on the second floor.
Thank you, mister. And you are the Copello and Co office guard, I suppose?
A night watch, William Lloyd.
Good job, Mr Lloyd. We'll finish soon and I might have a few questions then.
That room is a stalker's nest indeed. Are you prone to spy on people, Mr Lloyd?
I'm a watchman. What's wrong if I watch?
What do you know about the attempt to crack the safe?
How do you know about a break-in?
A break-in, then. Tell me, how exactly it happened.
Three days ago I was on my watch, heard a scream. Hurried upstairs to see what happened.
And there was a thief?
Yes. He ran to the balcony and escaped.
A break-in is a serious criminal offence. Why didn't you report about it to the police?
Lady Copello told me nothing serious happened.
Did you see the criminal? Can you describe him?
Got a scar so huge his cheek almost falls off. Any woman would scream seeing such a creep.
Were any other people in the office during the break-in?
Ehm... No. Only me. And the thief, of course.
You were not alone in the office that night. I think a lady was here and you are lying. Who was she?
Why do you ask? Want to take her away like you took the boss? I won't tell.
Then we have to go to the police and my colleague will look through all those notes and photos on your desk.
What? You won't do this. I'm innocent. I did nothing bad. Ask lady Augusta if you wish!
So Augusta Copello was here and can prove you're innocent? Did she notice the thief and screamed upstairs?
I didn't tell you! The kind lady always works that late... She's ill because this ugly bastard scared her!
Fine, Mr Lloyd. See you later.
Goodbye, officer.
Hmm... that does not make a lot of sense...
Do you recognize this? A stethoscope on your table. Just like the one used to open the safe. Care to explain?
I didn't listen to the safe! I... I listen in talks and such... but there is nothing interesting to listen in the safe!
What about the cog clicking? Or the pleas of the dying man inside?
No, no! I'm not interested in the dead! Why do you suspect me at all?! I was just doing my job!
You are not too persuasive, but I'll think about it. Stay here and don't try to escape.
Hello, handsome! Wanna have some fun with pretty Mary?
Not me, but my ugly friend. See that one, with the scars?
My, my, old Felix is so rude and ugly... Maybe we'll leave him here and have a nice walk behind the bar?
Not today, sweet Mary.
I'll take triple if you want me to have fun with this creep then.
Good news for you - no need to go that far. Just make him come to the room upstairs. Here's the pay.
Oh, you are that type of bored gentleman, eww... Fine, easy money! Just go up and wait a bit.
Hey, hey, guys, look who's coming! A policeman dog! Hey, officer, how about painting your pretty coat with some red from your sniffing nose?! Get him!
What the hell? You again? Where is Mary, you bastard!
We have to talk about Copello's office...
Are you some kind of a cop undercover? No one mess with Felix! Come here and I'll beat the shit out of you!
And I just wanted to talk. Why do you people like violence that much?
Huh... uh... who could know a pimp like you can hit so hard? Whatever... I did not kill the guy. You won't hang wet work on me... I just did what I was paid for, cracked the box...
I need the truth, not the closed case. I'm even not from the police.
Fine... ugh... fine. Ask what you want. I won't last... huh... another round like this.
So you were paid to crack the safe. Who did that?
The lady. Don't know the name. She ran to me in tears, pleaded to open the safe, paid a lot... I agreed, of course. Can't refuse a pretty lady.
What was your goal? What did you went after?
Don't know. I was paid for dealing with the lock, that's all.
So what happened in the Copello office?
I got on the balcony, and the lady let me in. I started my job and did it pretty well, even in a hurry. But when I opened the door, there was a dead guy!
She screamed, but not from fear. Guess she knew he is there, but not dead. So I told her I'm out of this and fled. Still can't get how did you find me.
Do you know who Norman Brown is? Have you ever met him?
Some rich pimp from Grand Saray. And I never met him. Such sissies don't have anything common with a man like me.
I have no questions for now. Good luck, Felix.
Screw you, mister funny hat. Watch around from now on.
Good day. Are you Mrs Augusta Copello?
That's me. I'm sorry, but who are you?
My name is Sherlock Holmes. I'm an investigator. Mr Copello hired me to get him out of jail.
Basilio hired you? Help him, please. I'm sure he's not guilty.
You'll help me a lot if you'll find a few minutes to answer my questions.
If it'll help my husband to get free, I'm at your service.
Do you know who is a man your husband found in the safe?
Oh... yes, I do. I... I'm not sure I can tell...
I just want to help Mr Copello. Please, tell me everything you know.
Norman... Mr Brown was not a good man. He and Basilli... they were business rivals. There was a lawsuit about a coal warehouse...
But I don't believe Basilli could do this to him!
What do you know about the safe? Who had access to it?
The safe... Just an old rusty box. I wanted Basilli to sell it. Everyone knew the code, but it stood open all the time.
I'm sorry to ask, but you look pale and your eyes... Are you ill?
Yes. Paid too much attention to work recently. Seems like my nerves demand a rest.
I can recommend you a skilled doctor from London...
Thank you for your kindness, but I'll cope myself. Help Basilli and I'm sure it will ease my illness a lot!
Sorry, Mrs Copello, but I have to go.
Tell me about the break-in attempt three days ago.
The break-in? But... how do you know?
I'm a detective, Mrs Copello. It's my job to know. So, what happened then?
I was working late... As usual. Heard some noise, then again. I was afraid and called a night watch. He got upstairs and we saw a scary man.
How did the villain look like?
Oh... I was so frightened! I don't remember him well... Just that he was very creepy. And we saw him only for a second, then he escaped.
The safe is in your cabinet, Mrs Copello. Were you away for some time?
Away... yes, I worked with other papers... in the other room. The workers always forget to bring me the documents, you know...
Have you checked what was stolen?
Nothing. He tried to crack the safe, but it's empty. I think he didn't know where to look for papers.
But wasn't the safe open already?
Open?... No, I don't think so. It was closed, but I didn't pay attention to it...
Why... cough... why couldn't you come later... cough... I'd be with Norman already...
Time cures, Augusta. And a woman like you should not waste your life in such a rude way. So, you and Norman...
We loved each other. We had our small paradise in this old office. Three months of happiness... but how painful it is to pay for our sins!
You tried to get him out of the safe, didn't you? Hired a safecracker, let him inside.
I did! Basilio changed the combination, and I couldn't let my Norman out! Why could he do that? Could he know about us? Oh yes, he knew. He did that on purpose!
He won't open the safe and get into prison then. No, Augusta, you could ask him about the password, but you were afraid.
And this kills me. I can't live with his blood on my hands. Why couldn't you let me finish all this?
You think all this to be Basilio's plan?
I don't know. I can't live with Norman's blood on my hands. But if Basilio knew all this, if he made me kill my love... oh, he should rot in jail forever!
I have to make decisions about all this situation, but I' afraid to leave you like that.
I... I don't have the courage to do this again. No, not again. Do what you want, I don't care about my fate anymore.
If the police won't put me in jail, I'll go to the monastery myself. Someone has to repent our sins, and maybe the Almighty will take me to Norman again after.
I've seen some shady characters on the bogs, guarding some old cave.
I know who you're talking about, and their boots must be sturdy stuff, 'cause mine are already ruined from all this dampness.
We've been meaning to pay them a visit and look into them, but I can't send the boys in blind. I'm a black ship in this precinct already.
Isn't it your duty to protect the island? Or that's for sunnier days?
Look, those tunnels have been closed for years - without a map my men might get lost. What then, send another team just to find them?
Another blunder like that and they'll reassign me to freeze my arse off on Falklands.
Appreciate it, sir.
You stay calm and keep your feet dry, I'll think of something.
I see. Goodbye then.
Stay safe and keep your feet dry.
What are you doing out on the bogs? Get inside before the coppers see you!
Right on.
Spare a coin for the good ol' Pete, kind sir? Please, I haven't eaten in days!
Sure, mister. Here you go and now, please, can you go expunge your incredible body odor somewhere else?
God bless you, sir!
Sorry, not today. Meanwhile, the time you spend sitting here could be better used searching for a job.
Eh, I tried, but I'm too old now. Served the Lauderdale family for three decades and they kicked me out for spilling a cup of tea!
I tried to find something else but I'm too weak for fishing or working in the gardens. Or do you think I simply like to grovel for coin?
Take this from a professional finder: if you can't find something, you're just not looking hard enough. Have a good day.
Hey! Leave that gentleman alone, you ruffians!
And what are you gonna do, dandy boy?
Let me introduce you to my friends: sir Jab, Mr. Hook and, of course, lord Uppercut!
Say, if I give you a sovereign and promise not to call the police - will that be enough for you?
Well-well, we have a benefactor here, guys. Less work for us, though. Alright, give what you got and we'll be on our way.
Thank you! I knew you won't leave a man in trouble from the time we met first! But I don't think we're properly acquainted. My name's Peter Crowley.
Well... Sherlock Holmes, at your service.
Oh, so you are the Sherlock Holmes, London's best sleuth? I can't believe my owns eyes, sir! Actually, I know what I can do for you.
I noticed your house could use some, you know, cleaning. I can do that! Still up for it, don't you worry!
That sounds reasonable, actually, since Mrs. Hudson is not here. How much do you want?
Hm-m. Would humble two sovereigns a month be acceptable?
I can spare that much. Here are some rules: first thing in the morning that I should see is a cup of tea with milk.
Second: don't touch any of my equipment. And third: stay quiet when I'm thinking. That's it.
Will do, sir. When can I start?
Right after you take a proper bath and buy some decent clothes. Go now.
I don't think I need your services. I can handle my own household. Have a nice day, sir.
Hey! Leave that gentleman alone, you ruffians!
And what are you gonna do, dandy boy?
Let me introduce you to my friends: sir Jab, Mr. Hook and, of course, lord Uppercut!
Say, if I give you a sovereign and promise not to call the police - will that be enough for you?
Well-well, we have a benefactor here, guys. Less work for us, though. Alright, give what you got and we'll be on our way.
Well-well, look what a cat has brought us here! A wealthy fish, don't you think boys?
I am not playing the victim if not with the Turk.
What? Who do you think I am?
Broken Brad. But your fake scar is poorly done. Do your boys draw it? Oh! Maybe they don't know.
What? I will crush your head.
Too bad the Turk is not here! It would be a pleasant fight!
The Turk never does the same place twice. He is too clever for that. No need to wait for him.
Let's see...
I'd recognize a fellow chemist from a mile afar. Good day, sir. What are you selling?
Well if it isn't Sherlock Holmes himself! Welcome to my humble shop. Finest chemicals for the finest prices! Found something to your liking?
Wouldn't hurt to restock my supply.
No, thanks.
Oh, before you go, can I ask you for a little favor?
What is it?
I've bought these two figurines for my collection of local arts, but I have a feeling that something isn't quite right with them.
These are supposed to be from Emin-pasha's fabled collection, if you know about it. Can you please check if they are genuine or not?
Your help will be rewarded, of course.
I've found the genuine figurine. It's the one on the right.
But Sherlock, how?
It's elementary, my dear friend. I did my homework and learned how the crest of Emin-pasha looks like. You should've done that too.
Thank you! Here's some more chemicals from my personal reserve. For your trouble.
Mr Holmes, At last!
Yes?
Sorry to bother, my name is Zachariah Bennett and I've been fooled horribly.
A frequent situation, I'm afraid.
I beg you p...? I was given a great job some time ago and I did my best to fulfill it. but my employer suddenly disappeared leaving me with no means to live.
Can I inquire as to the duties you were doing?
I've been hired as...a painter. An artist.
A painter? most extraordinary. Pray continue.
Where this work was tented do?
The place is on the port.
Where can I find you?
I live in a board house for veterans.
Justin Flockhart from the War Ministry, a man in his thirties with dark hair, clean hands and all that.
Please help me, they promised me this pension and now I have nothing.
A painter? most extraordinary. Pray continue.
I will.
Some time ago, I responded to a job offer. A job reserved for veterans. I went to the address, and I was told it was about drawing War monuments in memory of English heroes.
Statues based on drawings will be erected at the center of the English villages to recall the sacrifice of our people for the empire.
I had books to learn how to draw but no one to tell me, besides I have only my left hand now. I was promised me that if the work goes well, I would get an additional pension.
I'm a war Veteran and I lost me arm in Afghanistan near Kandahar. I was sent here to recover, but, like many of the soldiers, there is little waiting for us at home.
Will you help me?
I did my best, my real best and Flockhart told me that I was making progress. Here are my drawings, he told that within one or two months, it will get perfect.
But 3 days ago, I went back to my work and the place was closed. It was saying that the War Memorial Project was canceled. I couldn't get my last drawings.
Fascinating.
I was hired immediately, it was nice because I don't have a job since I lost my arm, and I started right away.
You worked alone?
I'm looking for Zachariah Bennett.
Bennett should be in his room, on the 3rd floor.
Thank you.
Good day to you. Can I ask you a few questions?
Most Certainly.
Goodbye.
Good Day, madam
Good Day, Sir. Welcome to Diazzola

Is she selling it?
Her suitor was in love with her and was promised to get her hand.
Unfortunately he died suddenly, in a very bizarre gardening incident. They even never met.
She Married someone else, but now she is in her seventies, she feels her bond with this past need to be cut.
A delicate heart! What a wonderful story!

What is your real name?
Andrew Phillips...

I met Bennett in Kandahar, in the hospital. He was very bad already.
Bennett got gangrene and died one night. He had no family. I took his disk and I found clothes my size.

Yes, I'm useless now, no one will hire a cripple.

You won't get a wounded soldier pension in this life.
Oh no, Mister Holmes, I should have never contacted you.
You took yourself for Zaccariah Bennett and then for a painting artist.
You've been fooled, but you fooled yourself first.
About that military pension, you earned it after all. But you'll have to be someone else for the rest of your life.
Thank you, Mister Holmes. I'll never forget that.
Nevermind. Forget about it.
Mr. Holmes, why did you talk to the administrator about the job?
It was a part of my investigation.
Now they want me to pay for the past months, do you understand what you have done?!
I apologize I didn't realize it was going to create you troubles.
Oh...it's too late now anyway.
Respecting rules is what you should have done. You were not honest with the people who feed and Shelter you.
...and took my arm. condemning me to a life of poverty and dependence.
Mr. Bennett, I successfully finished the investigation. The criminal was cached and will be punished.
But what with the money he owes me?
Let me pay for your work. At the end of the day, I was... quite impressed with your work.
Oh, thank you, Mr. Holmes! You are the kindest soul of all Gollanza!
It doesn't matter. Justice is only important, Mr. Bennett.
Oh... Well, if you say so, Mr. Holmes.
Mr. Barak? I am Sherlock Holmes. Tell me everything.
I do not know, sir, I do not know! When I came home, the devil had already taken her. Taken my dear Safiye...
When did you come home?
Before dawn. I work until late night - me and Safiye both did our part for the family. Oh, I should not have left her that night!
Do you suspect anybody?
But how can I? Who could be this... fiend?! Who would do such a thing?
My Safiye was like a fine rose. She drew stares! I was envied for her... But why kill her then, and not me? Why her?!
What ails your daughter?
A terrible affliction she was born with. Melisa used to get angry, see things, strike at Safiye and call her names.
Then a couple of months ago it changed - she became weak instead, bedridden. As if something sapped at her strength.
And you suspected nothing?
I prayed for my daughter's health every day. Perhaps I have finally been heard?
I found a threatening letter in your house. Do you know anything about it?
What is this?! Safiye told me nothing about it! Oh, when I get my hands on that fiend!...
Would you happen to know the sender?
No! If I did, he'd be learning to walk on broken legs now, and he never would have touched my Safiye!
Oh, what have we done to deserve such a thing...
How come your wife did not tell you about this?
Safiye knew how to play a man's heart, it helped her sell her wares. Got her in trouble sometimes, too.
But I was always there to defend her honour. Why she wouldn't call upon me now... that I do not know.
I will be back when I have more questions.
I will stay strong, Mr. Holmes.
I found burnt clothes in your oven.
You did?! So we have the killer's trace now!
Alas, it's too badly burnt for that. But it might still serve a purpose...
Mr. Barak, you won't like this. It seems Melisa is the killer.
How can you say such a thing! Did we not have enough grief in this house?!
I have reasons to believe your wife was keeping your daughter sedated so as not to deal with her outbursts.
But she was so weak...
Because of the medicine your wife kept her on.
No. This isn't happening. How does a man believe that?! Oh, but you're telling me the truth, aren't you...
Untreated, Melisa's condition worsened.
I must take the blame for this. If only I had been home more, kept an eye over the two of them!
Have Melisa institutionalized. She needs oversight and care, not being sedated into docility.
You're making me choose between honour and family, Mr. Holmes.
Your martyrdom can wait. Learn from your mistakes instead.
I wonder how out of touch with your family you've been to let the matter come to this.
Yes. Give me a few moments, and I will speak with the police. I will be convincing.
Stay home with your daughter. Neither of you needs to suffer more, but this time you make things right.
What are you saying?
That this is all a terrible, if understandable turn of events, and the punitive system will only make matters worse.
Leave the island, take your daughter somewhere she can get help. Be free, as long as no innocent is accused of this crime.
I see. Thank you, Mr. Holmes. You put more faith in us than I do.
Good afternoon!
Here is my invitation to the Annual Auction.
I'd recognize you even without it, sir Alfonso. You're welcome!
Signor Holmes. Signor Holmes! Did you hear the latest news? Mamma mia, it's terrible!

Oh no, signor, far worse! Karim is dead! Found murdered in an alleyway in a whole pond of his own blood!
Tell me two things. Who's this Karim and Why Is It Important?

Legendary Karim of the Silver Hand returned from beyond the grave to help the common folk of Gollanza!
Nonsense. Nobody can rise from the dead.
Yet he did, exactly like the legend tells. He watched over the town during the night, punishing ruffians and protecting us! Like a ghost, never caught once!
Until recently. Is he some kind of a vigilante then?
It sounds really dull, when you put it like that signor Holmes. Yes, you could say so.
I don't have time for petty murders right now. Most probably it's another unlucky lover who was found in the wrong bed at the wrong time.
Well, I'm used to newspapers calling me "legendary", thanks to Dr. Watson's novels, but what about this Karim? What's his legend?
I won't take more of your time, signor Holmes. There's a whole chapter dedicated to him in the "Myths and Legends of Gollanza".
You have one in your collection, if I'm not mistaken.
At least this sound entertaining. Do you know where all of this happened?
Yes, yes. Give me your map and I'll show you. Here!
Much obliged, signora Alsatti. And now it's time for me to bust some myths.
Good day, Mr. Holmes! I was just wondering when you'd show up.
Well, here I am, Lt. Placido. What do we have?
Frankly, not much. The guy was a silly masked vigilante, he overestimated himself and finally got stabbed by a bandit, I suppose.
He has been a nuisance for some time already, but we couldn't catch him. If we did - he'd still be alive.
Your help will be much appreciated, Mr. Holmes. This costume-and-mask stuff seems like something of your league.
Legends don't just die every day. I feel there's something more behind this. I take the case.
Thank you, Mr. Holmes.
Who reported this crime?
A bystander, local baker. He's over there, near the cart. You're free to question him.
He also seems to know the victim.
Lieutenant, do you know who the victim is?
His face seems pretty familiar, yes, but I can't just put my finger on it.
Ask at the police department. I still have all that pesky British bureaucracy to do here.
Hey! What is the meaning of this?! How did you get in?!
I took the front door, wasn't much of a bother at all.
You son of a... I'll kick your skull in!
There's been an incident at your neighbour's, the police is already looking into it. Mind clearing a few things up?
Police?! You're not telling them anything, you hear me?! And you're not leaving!
Who are you? I need a name.
Rade Zoric, I do odd jobs around here.
Why, do you have an alibi or I need to take your word as a trustworthy citizen?
Because... because I had my eye on her even before she ended up with that Turk. It wasn't me!
We shall see.
Answer me this...
You're a drug peddler, and don't deny it - you'd be insulting both of our intelligences.
A medicine peddler, all right? Medicine! These are hard times. People need something to take the edge off.
Maybe Safiye did too. She's been buying from me for a couple of months now.
The threatening letter left at Mrs. Barak's house led me here. Now, why did you feel the need to threaten a lokum seller?
Wait, what letter? This proves nothing.
Yet it led me to the yellow curtains.
Please, yellow curtains! Everyone in this house knows who lives here. Gossiping bastards.
I'm taking you to the police.
Don't! You can't do this to me, man!
Then come see them yourself. You are a suspect already - don't make your case worse by hiding from the police.
Damn it. All right. But I didn't do it, you hear me?!
I'll be back when I have questions.
Ay amico, see something you like? C'mon, don't be shy, Polidoro always has the best! Genuine Gollanzan antiquities! I swear by my mother's grave!
Actually, I wanted to ask if you recognize this man. Uzay Behcet.
Sh-h! Don't be so loud. Yes, Uzay is a good friend of mine. What about him?
What was that about a favor?
Oh, it's nothing. Uzay owed me money. Yeah, that's it.
He's dead. Murdered in an alleyway. Lots of blood, gruesome death. Nothing too interesting.
Name's Sherlock Holmes, by the way. I'm a consulting detective and I investigate this case.

I suppose you've heard the legend of Karim of the Silver Hand. It turns out that Uzay was behind the mask all this time.
It was foolish to do that and he should've seen it coming. This night he was stabbed to death.
Danazzione! It was him all along! Is this how one returns a favor?! After all that I did!
I'm very sorry, but Uzay was found murdered recently.
Oh, santo cielo! This is horrible! But how?
My name is Sherlock Holmes, I'm a consulting detective and I investigate this case.
Have a good day.
He was an overseer of this market. But, you know, an informal one. He collected money and offered us protection.
And I paid, I swear by the grave of my mother I paid! And I was safe from everyone. Except Karim. That guy took my shop as a personal insult, it seems.
What did he do?
He started spreading these filthy rumors about my wares being fake! Can you imagine? Me selling fake stuff!
Oh, my buisness was almost ruined! And then those cretinos that call themselves "street performers" made a "satyrical play" about this!
I swear by my mother's grave, they and Karim were in cahoots! But this is outrageous! I paid Uzay money for protection and he just mocked me! Cavolo!
Look, Polidoro, I don't want to bring you any trouble. But the police really wants to know who killed the local legend.
I don't want to involve them, because they wouldn't figure anything anyway, but they just might get the wrong person. And we don't want that to happen, do we?
Eh, amico, it's always a pleasure to talk to a sensible person in these parts. Well, Uzay was, how should I put it...
Don't worry, take your time.
I want to pay a visit to these performers. Where can I find them?
Their tent is right over there, can't miss it. I really hope you'll find something.
And good riddance to Karim. Finally got what he deserved!
You tell that Uzay was your friend, yet when I mentioned that he was Karim, you became upset. It seems that the three of you have some history.
Not something that I would tell you.
Well, I am a consulting detective and I cannot demand anything from you, but maybe Lt. Placido will have more luck than me?
Taking into account how much of your stock is probably stolen.
Oy, amico, no need for such drastic measures. You could just ask politely, you know. Well, Uzay was, how should I put it...
As is.
That makes no sense to me.
Welcome back, Mr. Berg. How was your performance?
Absolutely astonishing. The public were excited, standing ovations, flowers at my feet! I performed the whole "Four Seasons" flawlessly.
That's why they call me the Golden Accordion, the One-Man Orchestra!
Glad to hear it!
Bah, those simpletons! They didn't like my new experimental suite. So what if I completely disregarded all the musical structures and such.
Art is supposed to have no rules or boundaries! They are for boring snobs that only know how to make the same formulaic stuff.
Well, better luck next time.
Hey, do you know where ol' Uzay is?
Oh, Mr. Berg, didn't you hear the latest news? That old boot-licker was shanked this night, dressed as Karim!
That is most unexpected!
Hardly so. Suits him just right, after what he did to us. Petra is still in the hospital, Marcus now needs a whole new upper jaw!
And Giacomo, the stunt choreographer, was recovering for a week after the last beating Uzay gave him!
I'll get going.
I'm looking for Zachariah Bennett.
Bennett should be in his room, on the 3rd floor.
Thank you.
The rent and food are covered by the Army unless our pensioners find a work of their own.
This is a boarding house for Her Majesty overseas discharged wounded soldiers. They rest here until being sent back home.
What is this place?
Do you happen to have heard of a Monument job?
Can't say I have, Sir.
Good day to you. Can I ask you a few questions?
Most Certainly.
Goodbye

What work? if Bennett is working he should declare it, and pay for the rent and food here.
He works as a painter until 3 days ago, don't you know anything about that?
I certainly do not, but I'll send for Bennett right away to clear this.
Sorry, I was confused. Obviously not work.
Oy! Get over here you costumed boot-licker! C'mon boys, let's show him how to mess with us!
Karim of the Silver Hand doesn't know fear! Get ready for a walloping, you ruffians!
Good Day, madam.
Good Day, Sir. Welcome to Diazzola!
I see that there an exhibit soon, if the Emerald a famous Jewel?
It is indeed sir, it was offered to the Baroness of Tottington when she was 17. It's coming from the Amazonian forest.
Is she selling it?
Her suitor was in love with her and was promised to get her hand.
Unfortunately, he died suddenly, in a very bizarre gardening incident. They even never met.
She Married someone else, but now she is in her seventies, she feels her bond with this past need to be cut.
